source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk1

evidence_span: Four of the tubes, with a wall thickness variation less than 0.00l in.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk1
evidence_span: The fifth tube was from a different ingot, and although produced by the same fabrication route, it was introduced into the program because it had a larger wall thickness variation (0.0010 to 0.0018 in.).

evidence_span: It was also found that the wall thickness of Tube 5 was about 0.001 in. thicker than Tubes 1 to 4, which all had approximately the same wall thickness.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: The UHS results show two distinct groupings: Test Procedures 1-A and 4 are at about 140 ksi for Tubes 1 to 4, and Test Procedures 1-B, 2-A, 2-B, and 3 are at about 130 ksi.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk3
evidence_span: The UHS results show two distinct groupings: Test Procedures 1-A and 4 are at about 140 ksi for Tubes 1 to 4, and Test Procedures 1-B, 2-A, 2-B, and 3 are at about 130 ksi.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk4
evidence_span: The highest accuracy which can be hoped for using either method is $\pm 0 . 0 0 5$ in.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk4
evidence_span: Taking pre-test diameter and wall thickness measurements to within $\pm 0 . 0 0 0 1$ in. is justified only on the basis of calculating the UHS, not in computing the TCE.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk4
evidence_span: Although the two distinct groupings of UHS results differed in strength by almost 10 percent, they also showed close similarities. All tests showed Tube 5 as having the lowest strength, and most showed little difference between the other four tubes.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk4
evidence_span: Since Tube 5 was from a different ingot, processed at a different time and had a larger wall thickness variation, it could be expected to have somewhat different properties.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk4
evidence_span: As mentioned in the section on Pre-Test Measurements, the wall thickness measurements of the Test 1-A specimens are on the average 0.0017 in. smaller than those measured in Tests 2-A, 2-B, 3, and 4.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk4
evidence_span: This difference would make the Test 1-A UHS values about 8 percent higher than those determined by the other laboratories.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk4
evidence_span: If this amount is subtracted from the Test 1-A results, the average UHS values would range from 126.8 to 130.2 ksi, in excellent agreement with the results of Tests 1-B, 2-A, 2-B, and 3.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk4
evidence_span: The wall thickness measurements for Test 1-B specimens were also lower than for the other three tests, but only by an average of 0.0005 in.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk4
evidence_span: Since the average wall thickness was 0.0005 in. larger than the minimum wall thickness for the specimens of Test 1-A (measured on the same equipment) there is no net change in the ultimate hoop strength.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk4
evidence_span: Probably the explanation for the slightly higher UHS is because of the higher strain rate above yield, as mentioned in the section on Burst Test Apparatus.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk4
evidence_span: A comparison of the UHS of Test 2-A (with mandrel), with that of Test ?-B (no mandrel) shows that the mandrel has little influence on the UHS.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk4
evidence_span: Figure 5 shows that although the TCE results were not divided into two groups as were the UHS results, the scatter was about six times larger (calculating $\pmb { \sigma }$ as a percentage of the absolute measurement) and no consistent trends were evident.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk4
evidence_span: In every case where two comparable results are available, the mandrel containing specimens had the higher TCE.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk4
evidence_span: The average TCE increases as the diametral clearance of the mandrel decreases.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk4
evidence_span: The minimum value increases only slightly, whereas the maximum value increases quite markedly, indicating that the spread in the values also increases with decreasing diametral clearance, as had been found by Kallstrom [9].

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk4
evidence_span: This observation is consistent with Table 2 which shows that the standard deviation for all five tubes increases with decreasing diametral clearance.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk4
evidence_span: Kallstrom [9,10] has proposed that the presence of a mandrel increases the TCE because it prevents the specimen from bending.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: One of the participating laboratories imposes a limit of 130 ft·lb stored energy when the system is pressurized to 8000 psi with a thick-walled specimen in place.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: Increases in the strain rate tend to increase the UHS and decrease the TCE.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: Increases in the strain rate tend to increase the UHS and decrease the TCE.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: Increases in the stored energy of the pressurizing system tend to decrease the TCE.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk5
evidence_span: The presence of an internal mandrel increases the TCE, and it increases as the diametral clearance is decreased.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk6
evidence_span: Ultrasonic nondestructive inspection of fuel tubing can be made far more uniform and reliable by placing proper priority on the various test parameters

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk6
evidence_span: Ultrasonic nondestructive inspection of fuel tubing can be made far more uniform and reliable by placing proper priority on the various test parameters

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk6
evidence_span: Search units, for example, should be designed specifically for a given tube size, tube material, and quality assurance specification

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk6
evidence_span: Spectral compatibility in an ultrasonic inspection system is as important in achieving realistic test results as proper selection of search units

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk6
evidence_span: Ultrasonic nondestructive inspection of fuel tubing is a mainstay in the quality assurance program for nuclear fuel

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk6
evidence_span: Historically, this highly sensitive inspection has proven reliable in detection of defective tubing

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk6
evidence_span: Historically, this highly sensitive inspection has proven reliable in detection of defective tubing

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk6
evidence_span: However, it has shown a costly tendency to reject acceptable tubes by being, at times, overly sensitive

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk6
evidence_span: Ultrasonic inspection sensitivity is calibrated by adjusting the system to detect an artificially made defect (a reference notch of specified size and shape)

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk6
evidence_span: Hence, the system will detect and reject any material flaw having an effective reflecting surface equal to, or greater than, the reference notch thereby assuring quality tubing

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk6
evidence_span: This does not guarantee, however, that acceptable tubing will not be rejected and scrapped

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_005_chunk6
evidence_span: There are many instances where different firms, each inspecting tubes in accordance with the same procedure, have had significant disagreement in test results
